dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: So, GrayKey can't crack iPhones on iOS 12 or above anymore—what does that mean for law enforcement?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, GrayKey can't crack iPhones on iOS twelve or above anymore-what does that mean for law enforcement?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Multiple sources familiar with the GrayKey tech tell Forbes the device can no longer break the passcodes of any iPhone running iOS 12 or above.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, that's huge. It's a partial extraction now, so they only get unencrypted files and metadata, like folder structures.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, that's huge. It's a partial extraction now, so they only get unencrypted files and metadata, like folder structures.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: On those devices, GrayKey can only do whats called a partial extraction, sources from the forensic community said. That means police using the tool can only draw out unencrypted files and some metadata, such as file sizes and folder structures.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Right, and before, they were brute-forcing passcodes, getting around Apple's protections. But now, it seems like Apple's really upped their game.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, and before, they were brute-forcing passcodes, getting around Apple's protections. But now, it seems like Apple's really upped their game.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Previously, GrayKey used brute forcing techniques to guess passcodes and had found a way to get around Apples protections preventing such repeat guesses. But no more.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And Grayshift had contracts with big agencies too, like Immigration and Customs Enforcement and the Secret Service. They must be scrambling.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And Grayshift had contracts with big agencies too, like Immigration and Customs Enforcement and the Secret Service. They must be scrambling.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Grayshift continued to grow, however, securing contracts with Immigration and Customs Enforcement, and the Secret Service.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. And one of their founders is an ex-Apple security engineer, so if they can't crack it, who can?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. And one of their founders is an ex-Apple security engineer, so if they can't crack it, who can?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: And if its impossible for GrayKey, which counts an ex-Apple security engineer among its founders, its a safe assumption few can break iPhone passcodes.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Captain Jack Sherwood from the Saint Paul Police said it aligns with their findings, but he thinks a workaround will come eventually.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Captain Jack Sherwood from the Saint Paul Police said it aligns with their findings, but he thinks a workaround will come eventually.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Police officer Captain John Sherwin of the Rochester Police Department in Minnesota said of the claim iOS 12 was preventing GrayKey from unlocking iPhones: Thats a fairly accurate assessment as to what we have experienced.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: That cycle just keeps repeating, doesn't it? Apple builds a wall, someone finds a way over it.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That cycle just keeps repeating, doesn't it? Apple builds a wall, someone finds a way over it.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: But this time, it might be different. Vladimir Katalov from Elcomsoft—he's usually great at finding weaknesses—even he's stumped.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But this time, it might be different. Vladimir Katalov from Elcomsoft-he's usually great at finding weaknesses-even he's stumped.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Vladimir Katalov, chief of forensic tech provider Elcomsoft, has repeatedly uncovered weaknesses in Apple technology. But he was stumped too.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: No idea how Apple did it, huh? He mentioned better kernel protection or configuration-profile restrictions.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: No idea how Apple did it, huh? He mentioned better kernel protection or configuration-profile restrictions.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: It could be everything from better kernel protection to stronger configuration-profile installation restrictions, he suggested.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, the kernel is core to the OS, so if they've locked that down tighter...
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, the kernel is core to the O S, so if they've locked that down tighter...
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The kernel is the core part of the operating system, from which the rest of iOS launches.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Meanwhile, Grayshift is going global. TechCrunch says UK police are using GrayKeys now.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Meanwhile, Grayshift is going global. TechCrunch says U K police are using GrayKeys now.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Wiredrevealed last week that a number of U.K. police agencies are now using GrayKeys.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And Tim Cook's in Europe talking up privacy. Coincidence? Probably not.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And Tim Cook's in Europe talking up privacy. Coincidence? Probably not.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Meanwhile, Apple chief Tim Cook visited Europe this week, talking up the need for all tech companies to improve privacy for users.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: So Apple's winning this round, but you know the cat-and-mouse game isn't over.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So Apple's winning this round, but you know the cat-and-mouse game isn't over.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: For sure. Someone's always building a better mousetrap, like Sherwood said.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: For sure. Someone's always building a better mousetrap, like Sherwood said.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Someone is always building a better mousetrap, whether its Apple or someone trying to defeat device security.
